TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}

S.FORM: izua aya ta maretsekeł ti Tjukutjuku kati Pułałułałuyan; sa puałak tjai Muakakai tu nguanguaq aravats.
izoa aya ta marecekelj ti Tjokotjoko kati Poljaljoljaljoyan; sa poaljak tjai Moakakai to ngoangoaq aravac.
S.TRANSL: They say there was a married couple called Tjukutjuku and Pułałułałuyan. They had a very beautiful child called Muakakai.
The young men of the village fell in love with her;
and she married Kułełułełu, they say.
But they say her vagina had teeth.
They slept together,

S.FORM: manu katsen na kutji, sa patsay ti Kułełułełu.
mano kacen na kotji, sa pacay ti Koljeljoljeljo.
S.TRANSL: and he was bitten by her vagina, and so Kułełułełu died.

S.FORM: saka małianga, sa "pai, gatsału, kenamau anga," aya ti Tjukutjuku.
saka maljianga, sa "pai, gacaljo, kenamao anga," aya ti Tjokotjoko.
S.TRANSL: In the morning Tjukutjuku said: “Get up and have breakfast.”
But he was dead.

S.FORM: saka "aku matsay? su kinuda?" aya kivadaq a matjałałak.
saka "ako macay? so kinoda?" aya kivadaq a matjaljaljak.
S.TRANSL: “Why did he die? What did you do?” her parents asked.
Muakakai didn’t reply.

S.FORM: sa qaqivuin a sikataqałan ni Kułełułełu; saka mangtjez a malap.
sa qaqivoin a sikataqaljan ni Koljeljoljeljo; saka mangtjez a malap.
S.TRANSL: They told Kułełułełu’s people, and they came and took his body.

S.FORM: saka "masiaq itjen," aya ti Tjukutjuku kati Pułałułałuyan.
saka "masiaq itjen," aya ti Tjokotjoko kati Poljaljoljaljoyan.
S.TRANSL: “We’re ashamed of her,” said Tjukutjuku and Pułałułałuyan.

S.FORM: saka "sikudanga a ałak; tja łangianaw," aya, sa piłangian; saka paqałudj ta załum pasa pana.
saka "sikodanga a aljak; tja ljangianaw," aya, sa piljangian; saka paqaljodj ta zaljom pasa pana.
S.TRANSL: “What use is this child? We’ll put her in a trunk,” they said, and put her in a trunk, and let it float away on the water of the river.

S.FORM: saka izua se tjarivavaw ti Kułełułełu katua sikataqałan tjepanapana.
saka izoa se tjarivavaw ti Koljeljoljeljo katoa sikataqaljan tjepanapana.
S.TRANSL: Now a person from heaven called Kułełułełu was fishing in the river with his fellow-villagers.

S.FORM: sa djemumak anga ta łangian i taladj ta vatsał.
sa djemomak anga ta ljangian i taladj ta vacalj.
S.TRANSL: They found the trunk in a deep pool.

S.FORM: sa alapen saka qaluin a sema umaq; saka mangtjez i umaq.
sa alapen saka qaloin a sema omaq; saka mangtjez i omaq.
S.TRANSL: They took it and carried it home.
When they got home, he said: “Mother, father, we found a trunk.

S.FORM: aki anema i taladj? sadjelung aravats."
aki anema i taladj? sadjelong aravac."
S.TRANSL: What can be inside it? It’s very heavy.”
So they lifted the lid and looked inside.
“This must be Muakakai.

S.FORM: makełang aza puałis a kutji; siniverits na matjałałak, a siayaya."
makeljang aza poaljis a kotji; siniveric na matjaljaljak, a siayaya."
S.TRANSL: She is said to be well-known for her vagina with teeth, and for being thrown away by her parents.”
“Go off and hunt,” they said to Kułełułełu.
Muakakai went to sleep.

S.FORM: saka qetsapen aza ałis na kutji.
saka qecapen aza aljis na kotji.
S.TRANSL: And they pulled out the teeth from her vagina.

S.FORM: saka mangtjez ti Kułełułełu a naqemałup.
saka mangtjez ti Koljeljoljeljo a naqemaljop.
S.TRANSL: Kułełułełu came back from hunting.

S.FORM: saka masalud; saka inikanga matsay ti Kułełułełu.
saka masalod; saka inikanga macay ti Koljeljoljeljo.
S.TRANSL: They slept together, and Kułełułełu didn’t die.
So Muakakai became pregnant, and they had a child.
The teeth were called tatalaven ḍaḍamelamen.
They were valuable enough to be exchanged for land.

S.FORM: sepatj a ałis na kutji a qata.
sepatj a aljis na kotji a qata.
S.TRANSL: There are four vagina teeth beads;
one at Payuan,
two at Pełeti,
and one at Kaviangan.
amin
